title-group.article-title: Steady State Laffer Curve with the Underground Economy

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Francesco Busato is a professor in the Department of Economic and Legal Studies at University of Naples Parthenope. He received his PhD in economics and finance from Columbia University. Much of his research examines dynamic general equilibrium models with attention to tax evasion, preference shocks, and asset pricing.

Bruno Chiarini is a professor in the Department of Economic and Legal Studies at University of Naples Parthenope. He received his PhD in economics from Southampton. Much of his research focuses on tax evasion, labor market dynamics, and labor unions from a theoretical and applied perspective.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: The Shadow Economy, Tax Evasion, and Money Laundering

abstract.p: This article studies equilibrium effects of fiscal policy within a dynamic general equilibrium model where tax evasion and underground activities are explicitly incorporated. In particular, we show that a dynamic general equilibrium with tax evasion may give a rational justification for a variant of the Laffer curve for a plausible parameterization. From a revenue maximizing perspective, the key policy messages are that bringing tax payers to compliance would be better than threatening to punish them if convicted and that an economy without problems of compliance is much more sensitive to myopic behavior.

body.p: The Laffer curve is a graphical representation of the relationship between tax rates, tax revenue, and taxable income. This article discusses and evaluates the nexus among underground activities, tax evasion, and the existence of a Laffer curve in a dynamic general equilibrium model. It also examines the macroeconomic implications entailing the deceptive relationship between tax rates and tax revenues.

These issues are important for several reasons. First, as stressed by many authors (e.g., Feige 1989; McGee and Feige 1989; Schneider and Enste 2002; Schneider 2007; Schneider and Buehn 2012), the underground economy is a sizable and increasing phenomenon in terms of both output produced and labor input employed in all the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development economies. Second, the way in which tax revenues relate to the rate of tax has attracted much attention in the last thirty years, both theoretically and empirically, generating intense discussions among economists beginning with the seminal article by Laffer (1981). In particular, one of the most controversial issues in tax policy analysis is whether a tax cut will boost economic activity to such an extent that the government’s budget actually improves (often referred to as a Laffer’s curve effect). Finally, understanding these relationships may shed more light on why some countries, such as Italy, show a relevant fiscal burden. It should also help frame a better discussion on the financial austerity growth trade-off.

A Laffer curve can be defined as a curve that supposes that for a given economy there is an optimal income tax level to maximize tax revenues, which happens at the peak of the curve. If the tax rate is set below this level, raising taxes will increase tax revenues. If the tax level is set above this level, then lowering taxes will increase tax revenue.

The economic literature has drawn attention to the importance of the existence and shape of the Laffer curve, to the way government spends revenues, to the progressivity of the tax system, to the elasticity of supply, and to the preference for untaxed output, among other things. Here we show that in addition to the above structural and fiscal system effects, the underground economy and tax evasion deeply affect the Laffer curve with considerable consequences not only on the revenue-maximizing point but on the whole dimension of the relationship between tax rate and revenues.

With respect to our specific issues, the literature discussing the relationships between underground economy, tax evasion, and the Laffer curve spans from Palda (1998) and Sanyal, Gang, and Goswami (2000) to the more recent contributions of Stinepring (2011) and Cuñat, Dek, and Maffezzoli (2008). The literature on dynamic Laffer curves begins with Ireland (1994), who combines AK technology and inelastic labor supply with a single output tax in search of self-financing tax cuts, and Agell and Persson (2001), who study dynamic Laffer effects in an endogenous growth model.

Classical theory suggests that two most prominent deadweight losses in public finance are the triangle loss from taxation and the rectangle loss from rent seeking. Taking into account tax evasion (and with this, the underground sector), there exists a third type of deadweight loss that can rival these two in size and deserves detailed exploration. In the presence of the underground economy, taxes give rise to a deadweight loss from displacement of efficient producers by inefficient producers.

The existence and the shape of steady state Laffer curves, and the policy implications within the context of (dynamic) general equilibrium models were recently discussed by Trabandt and Uhlig (2011, 2012).

We are not aware, however, of other contributions investigating the nexus among the existence (and characteristics) of a Laffer curve and the presence of underground activities and tax evasion in a dynamic general equilibrium model. This is surprising since over the past few decades, tax increases and tax cuts in many countries have been remarkably unsuccessful in terms of achieving the desired effect over fiscal revenues and, therefore, in helping to balance the budgets.

This article precisely addresses that point. It aims to clarify the implication for such a curve when there exists a sizable underground sector with a well-defined economic structure. We therefore distinguish not only between the so-called standard arithmetic effect (i.e., movements along the Laffer curve via tax rates) and the economic effect (i.e., shifts of the curve via tax base), but we explicitly elicit the so-called compliance effect driven by the reallocation labor input from the regular to the irregular sector and vice versa.

In this context, revenue responses to a tax rate change are linked to the characteristic of the irregular production, its size, the ability of firms to shift labor input between the two sectors, the tax system (i.e., tax rates, probability of being detected and surcharged), the household preferences, and the incentives that the tax system provides them to offer labor input in the two sectors. This complex relationship between tax rates and revenues conveys important policy implications, and it is investigated by running the model with several simulations.

Setting up a two-sector dynamic general equilibrium model, we calculate and depict the geometrical expression of a reduced form of the equilibrium model concerning the relationship between tax rates and the government revenues.

The article is organized as follows: the second section presents the model, the third section calibrates the model, and the fourth section numerically derives the steady state Laffer curves with and without the contribution of the underground economy; fourth section also discusses a sensitivity analysis with respect to the main parameters of the model. The final section presents our conclusions.

sec.title: The Model Structure
sec.p: This article relies on a dynamic general equilibrium model. There are three agents in the model: firms, households, and the government. In addition, there are two sectors: the regular and the underground sectors. Firms and households are subject to distortionary taxation, but they can use the underground sector to evade taxes by reallocating labor services across sectors. The firms produce a homogeneous good by combining three production factors: physical capital, regular labor services, and irregular labor services. The latter represents the channel through which tax evasion is undertaken. The households choose consumption, investment, and hours to work on each date and in each sector (official and unofficial) to maximize the expected discounted value of utility, subject to a sequence of budget constraints, a proportional tax rate on regular income, and the law of motion for capital stock. 1 Finally, the government levies proportional taxes on revenues and incomes and balances its budget (in expected terms) for each period.

Before moving onto the calibration section, it is useful to discuss briefly the firm homogeneity assumption. Since all firms are implicitly assumed identical, the model relies on the notion of the representative firm. It would be interesting also to consider a model where firms can default, tackling by this means the issue of firm heterogeneity. We can think of a continuum of firms (a share of which could default on a period-by-period basis), or of a (relatively) simpler structure of two firms, either producing the same product or producing a slightly differentiated products but using the same production inputs. Such a model would be able to address a new, wider set of questions, both economic (e.g., strategic interaction) and technical (e.g., solving a model where the dimension of the economy [the state vector] changes on a period-by-period basis, depending on how many firms survived from previous period). However, this would lead not only to a new version of the model but would move to a different class of models; hence, it is left to future research.

sec.title: Steady State Laffer Curves
sec.p: This section presents the Laffer curve numerically constructed from the optimality conditions of our economy. Figure 1 separately plots Laffer curves for an economy with and without an underground sector, for the baseline parameterization. The curves are derived from the optimality equilibrium conditions evaluated at the stationary state derived in proposition 1, using the calibration described earlier.

caption.p: Laffer curves with (without) tax evasion for personal income tax rate and corporate tax rate.

Note: Top Panel: Laffer curves for corporate tax rate; bottom panel: Laffer curves for personal income tax rate; circles: Laffer curve without the underground sector; cross: Laffer curves with underground activities. The circle on top denotes the Laffer curve peak; the average income tax rate equals 36 percent, while average corporate tax rate is 37.5 percent.

sec.p: The model shows that a Laffer curve exists with and without an underground sector. Each panel reports the average tax rate and the peak of the curve, which reflects the maximum revenues. A casual glance at the previous figure suggests that, for the average income tax, there is a large gap between revenues actually collected and those that could potentially be collected in a perfectly compliant economy. The figures suggest that, for the baseline parameterization, the loss of tax revenues with the underground sector is considerable; for example, at the average income tax rate of 32.25 percent, the revenue gap is close to eight percentage points of aggregate gross domestic product (GDP).

Comparing the two figures, it is worth noting that the Laffer curve for corporate taxes (i.e., the top panel) does not end at zero for
τ
F
= 1
. This is the consequence of the fact, even when taxes collect all the output produced in the regular economy (which eventually collapses to zero), the underground sector is still producing. The latter production is subject, in expected terms, to distortionary taxation
τ
F
, weighted with the detection probability p and the surcharge factor s. In this sense, this hidden production produces a tax revenues cash flow in expected terms.

The Laffer curve under tax evasion is completely beneath the no-evasion Laffer curve for almost all tax rates. For very high income and corporate tax rates, the Laffer curve of the model augmented with the underground sector is above the regular counterpart.

The basic idea behind the relationship, distinguishes between a movement along the Laffer curve (arithmetic effect) and shifts of the curve itself (economic effect). The arithmetic effect is simply that, if tax rates are increased, tax revenues (per euro of tax base) will be increased by the amount of the increase in the rate; the reverse also holds. The economic effect takes into account the negative impact that higher tax rates have on equilibrium labor services and output and hence on the reduced tax base. Raising tax rates has the opposite economic effect by penalizing participation in the regular economy. Also here the reverse holds.

The conjecture that, if tax rates were increased, then tax revenues would increase has become a recurrent policy stand in countries with high deficits and debts. 9 While arithmetic and economic effects make the issue far from straightforward, in the presence of tax evasion, the tax policy is even more problematic: higher tax rates under tax evasion certainty do not guarantee fiscal solvency. In an economy with tax evasion, since the economic and the arithmetic effects of tax rate changes are combined, the consequences of the change in tax rates on total tax revenues are no longer quite so obvious.

In this context with a sizable underground sector, there exists a further effect to be considered whenever fiscal policy is undertaken: the compliance effects (Papp and Takats 2008). The underground sector, and hence tax evasion, allows for shifts of the curve itself. Revenue responses to a tax rate change will depend upon the tax system (e.g., tax rates and the characteristics of irregular production, probability of being detected, surcharge factors), the ease of movement in underground activity, the size of such activity, the level of the tax rates already in place, and agents’ preferences and constraints. The relationships described in the figures are a useful tool since they are derived from an underlying general model that is able to cope with optimal agent behavior in the context of an underground economy.

sec.title: Sensitivity on the Firm’s Side
sec.p: Concerning the firm, there are two interesting parameters/effects to consider: the surcharge factor s and the detection probability p, representing different channels through which the government may try to control tax evasion. By this means, they have an impact on the existence and shape of the Laffer curve under tax evasion. 10

The first aspect worth examining is how selected institutional policies for detecting and for eventually punishing dodgers affect the existence and shape of a Laffer mechanism in the steady state. To address this issue, we perform a sensitivity analysis exercise with respect to the surcharge factor s and detection probability p. 11 The top panel in Figure 2 shows the relationship between corporate tax revenues and government revenues for two different values of
s =
1.3 ; 2.0
, the two values that are currently in place for the Italian economy. A surcharge of
s = 1.3
implies that the convicted dodger pays a 30 percent more than the due value, which applies when the tax evaders confess and pays the penalty to the authorities. The latter value of
s = 2.0
means that the convicted dodger pays a 100 percent more than the due value, which applies when the tax evaders is eventually convicted and forced to pay the fine after legally contesting the action of the tax administration.

sec.p:
The bottom panel in the same figure plots the case for a more complex policy exercise, depicting the consequences of more severe fines that range from s = 5.0 to s = 20.0. Casual inspection suggests that the surcharge factor does not affect the firm’s decision to operate in the underground economy and hence tax revenues, unless the fine is extremely high. For a penalty close to s = 20.0 or higher, the Laffer mechanism tends to disappear. Note that collected revenues almost monotonically grow up to

Figure 3 presents the response of the steady state Laffer curve for the corporate tax rate to a sensitivity analysis exercise with respect to detection probability. The figure suggests that an increase in detection probability does not significantly affect the Laffer curve for relatively low levels of tax rates, while it matters for relatively high tax rates. In other words, an increase in detection probability shifts the peak of the curve to the right. When detection probability gets even higher (i.e., above p = 50%), the Laffer curve almost disappears, replaced by a monotonically growing schedule. The peak is reached for
τ

, suddenly dropping afterward. This also means that what really matters is the effective penalty ps. This is due to the fact that the effective penalty becomes sufficiently binding for the dodger only when exceeds 50 percent.

sec.title: Sensitivity on the Household’s Side
sec.p:
Figure 4 describes the effects on the Laffer curve of a variation in
B u
, the parameter measuring the utility cost in supplying labor in the underground sector and identifying the personal cost of operating in the underground economy. 12 Increasing the idiosyncratic costs of working in the informal sector (e.g., social and health insurance, tax moral) has two effects. First, it shifts the labor supply over the ground for relatively lower tax rate levels; in this case, more revenues will be collected for the same tax rate, ceteris paribus. Second, it shifts to the right the peak of the Laffer curve evaluated under tax evasion (cross line in the figure).

caption.p: Sensitivity exercise with respect to disutility costs.

Notes: Circles: Laffer curve without the underground sector; cross: Laffer curves with underground activities, where the lower (higher) curves depicts the schedule for β = 0.92. The circle on top denotes the Laffer curve peak.

sec.p:
The disutility parameter
B u
reflects, in some sense, the role of compliance. Its effect can be compared with the consequences of changes into the enforcement parameters s and p. The compliance effect and a more extensive and prolonged arithmetic effect (i.e., the rightward shift of the peaks) follow from the combined effect of a tax increase under a higher disutility from allocating labor services to the underground sector.

Given the technology structure, comparison between figures 2 and 4 clearly suggests that a tight policy against the underground sector based on punishment and fines would not be as effective as a policy operating through the disutility parameter into the utility function. For example, increasing the social cost of offering labor supply in underground activities and convincing actual (and potential) workers that operating in the underground economy is socially disapproved would in each case ensure a higher tax revenue profile. The key policy message is that to bring taxpayers to compliance would be better, from a revenue maximizing perspective, than threatening to punish them if convicted.

Figure 5 presents the consequences of a reduction in the deterministic intertemporal discount factor β to 0.92 from the baseline value of 0.96. Increasing the steady state value for the interest rate (i.e., reducing the discount factor) provides interesting results: a drop in the regular economy Laffer curve (and tax revenues) and a small reduction in the evasion Laffer curve. Thus, an economy without compliance problems is relatively more sensitive to myopic behavior; that is, more consumption today and less investment tomorrow reduce income and the tax base. In an economy with an underground sector, this effect is offset by the labor shift to the irregular market. In this sense, the irregular sector provides a sort of insurance for hard times.

caption.p: Sensitivity exercise with respect to interest rate (inter-temporal discount factor).

Notes: Circles: Laffer curve without the underground sector; crosses: Laffer curves with underground activities, where the lower (higher) curves depicts the schedule for β = 0.92, and β = 0.96, Bu = 3.5. The circle on top denotes the Laffer curve peak.

sec.title: Conclusion and Policy Discussion
sec.p: There are two important lessons for fiscal policy that our analysis produces and that can be generalized to other countries. The first concerns the differences in the Laffer curve across countries. As stressed by Trabandt and Uhlig (2012), these are typically linked to differences in fiscal policy (i.e., the mix of distortionary taxes, government spending, and government debt). For instance, they find that labor income and consumption taxes are important for accounting for most of the cross-country differences. Our analysis stresses that these differences in fiscal policy are smoothed in the presence of a sizable underground sector. The Laffer curve may be shifted because it moves with underground sector. Moreover, our sensitivity analysis implies that these differences should also be related to the different institutional policies for detecting and punishing dodgers.

A further lesson that can be drawn from our analysis concerns the evaluation of the effect of fiscal policies. In recent years, policy makers have implemented an array of discretionary fiscal measures to stimulate economic activity and soften the economic downturn. At the same time, almost all European economies have implemented rules for budget discipline, increasing taxation, and reducing public spending. The empirical literature often provides numerical estimates of the impact of an increase in government spending and tax rates on GDP and employment in the United States and in European countries. Such estimates contribute to determine the appropriate size and timing of countercyclical fiscal policy packages. Uncertainty about the quantitative effects of fiscal policy derives not only from the usual errors in empirical estimation but also from different views on the suitable theoretical framework and econometric methodology (Basile, Chiarini, and Marzano 2011; Busato, Chiarini, and Rey 2012). Our analysis emphasizes that a crucial source of uncertainty is tied to the size of tax evasion and the consequent compliance effect.

Two questions naturally arise in evaluating the effects of fiscal policy. First, can we rely upon fiscal policy multipliers estimated in countries with unreported production of 15 percent (or more) of GDP? Second, how will taxable income change in response to changes in the rate of taxation in the presence of unreported production? These questions are relevant to many economies such as the Italian economy and most other economies in Mediterranean Europe. However, they can be generalized to other European countries and even to the US economy, where unreported production and tax evasion statistics are rare, and the methods employed to calculate the phenomenon are not entirely clear. We leave to future research the generalization of our findings to those obtained for all the countries with sizable unreported production realizing. That said, it is clear that the Laffer curve moves with the underground economy, and awareness of this fact should lead to better tax policy design.

When assessing the impact of tax legislation, our model suggests that it is imperative to start measuring the effect of the tax policy only after serious analysis of the reallocation mechanism among sectors (overground and underground) and the existing incentives and disincentives that drive the shadow behaviors. This suggestion is obvious when the size of the tax evasion is considerable. Although many countries such as Italy have underground sectors that account for 15 to 27 percent of GDP (e.g., Busato, Chiarini, and Rey 2012; Busato and Chiarini 2004; Schneider and Buehn 2012), it is hard to find traces of this reasoning in government policy documents and in the setting of tax policy measures. In these circumstances, government policies that rely on estimated tax effects that neglect the underground economy are far from convincing. If we assume the economy locates on the downward-sloping segment of the Laffer curve, a tax increase provides misleading effects on revenues. In fact, revenues are dramatically lowered by the shrinking of the Laffer curve, pushing people to allocate as much as possible resources in the underground sector. The economic effects of tax policy would create an incentive to drop output, employment, and production in the official sector, increase tax evasion, and outweigh the arithmetic effect of the tax increase upon government revenues. If instead we assume that the economy is on the upward-sloping segment of the curve, and if the government neglects the shadow sector, then the increase in tax rates dramatically overestimates the outcome in terms of revenues. Precisely, it fails to estimate the economic effect (i.e., in the official GDP the underground component is taken into account), and therefore the policy effect reduces to achieve only the arithmetic effect of the underground Laffer curve.
